This is most conveniently made using `spatstat`, but I've shown it here making a point pattern into an `sf` dataset and then using `sf::st_voronoi()`. 


::: {.cell hash='fig2-07-point-voronoi_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-1_3c7237af530d8e1ab3af4ec4f18f556f'}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(spatstat)
library(sf)
library(tmap)
```
:::


There are a few steps making a `spatstat` point pattern into a simple features dataset...


::: {.cell hash='fig2-07-point-voronoi_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_83ee820924418b8ca959c1984e30ac0a'}

```{.r .cell-code}
pp <- rpoispp(100) %>%
  as.data.frame() %>%
  st_as_sf(coords = c("x", "y"), crs = 2193)
```
:::


And there are a few more making a point dataset into a Voronoi polygon dataset.


::: {.cell hash='fig2-07-point-voronoi_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-3_3cbf2f9bbec3e7d8f72ba10fd0763c13'}

```{.r .cell-code}
pp_vor <- pp %>%
  st_union() %>%
  st_voronoi() %>%
  st_cast() %>%
  st_as_sf(crs = st_crs(pp))
```
:::


And finally a map.


::: {.cell hash='fig2-07-point-voronoi_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-4_8e209ce9855369fab3a72a96aa6fd13e'}

```{.r .cell-code}
tm_shape(pp_vor, bbox = pp %>% st_union() %>% st_buffer(0.05)) + 
  tm_polygons(border.col = "white") +
  tm_shape(pp) + 
  tm_bubbles(col = "white", alpha = 0, border.col = "black", size = 0.1) +
  tm_layout(frame = FALSE)
```
